sub_title: Director Digital Science & Technologies at dsm-firmenich | Innovators in Health, Nutrition & Beauty
summary:
I co-lead the Center for Digital Innovation together with Daniel Grenfell-Lee. We are part of DSM’s Science & Innovation unit Biodata & Translation established In 2022. The global Center has five global Teams: Translational Data Science & Insights, Data Analytics, Bioinformatics and Modeling, Lab4.0 & Automation, Data Automation & Analytics.

Our global Teams work from the offices and labs in Delft, the Netherlands; Heerlen, the Netherlands; Kaiseraugst, Switzerland; Lexington, US; Columbia; US. We team-up in Science & Innovation projects with our colleagues in Animal Nutrition & Health, Human Nutrition & Care, Taste, Texture & Health, and Biosciences & Process Innovation.

Besides, I am currently assigned as Senior Science Fellow Bioinformatics, Modeling & Data Science. My previous functions at DSM involved R&D management and strategy for the (i) Bio-design & Modeling, and (ii) the Biofab lab automation groups. 

Over the years, I have managed multidisciplinary project teams for Industrial Biotech projects and support, involving: high-throughput screening, automated strain engineering, protein engineering, metabolic pathway engineering, omics data mining, sequencing, biostatistics and big data. 

I am experienced, working in innovation projects with filamentous fungi, yeast and bacteria: Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Kluyveromyces lactis, Aspergillus niger, Penicilium chrysogenum, Mortierella alpina, Bacillus subtilis, Escherichia coli and more. 

Memberbership: BE-BASIC, KNCV, NBV, NBIC, STW, SynBERC, EBRC, DTL, H2020-DD-DeCaF, ITN Syncrop, ITN PAcMEN, EU-Shikifactory100.

Google Scholar pubs:
http://scholar.google.com/citations?user=v5NwkC4AAAAJ&hl=en

The academic and industrial partners of SynCrop will work synergistically to generate a cohort of well-trained young scientists with inter-disciplinary skills in quantitative biology, cell biophysics, cell engineering and microbial physiology. 

Researchers with such a broad spectrum of training are lacking due to the fragmentation of the emerging field of synthetic biology across Europe and because the need, nature and magnitude of these new skills are only now emerging. The SynCrop Network will equip our Early Stage Researchers (ESRs) with unique combination of skills essential to become future research leaders or entrepreneurs in the emerging field of synthetic biology. They will drive this research field forward and accelerate the development of novel production platforms for exopolysaccharides (EPS), vitamins and carotenoids at reduced R&D costs.
